- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors did not mention whether they assessed the likelihood of publication bias.
- Response: [No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors did not mention any potential conflicts of interest.
- Response: [No]


P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
- Quote: "Comparison of the Nuss and the Ravitch procedure for pectus excavatum repair: a meta-analysis"
- Reasoning: The title clearly identifies the report as a meta-analysis.
- Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- Quote: "Abstract: Purpose: Pectus excavatum is the most common chest wall deformity in children. Two procedures are widely applied—the Nuss and the Ravitch. Several comparative studies are published evaluating both procedures with inconsistent results. Our objective was to compare the Nuss procedure to the Ravitch procedure using systematic review and meta-analysis methodology."
- Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the review, including the background, objectives, data sources, methods, results, and conclusions.
- Response: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- Quote: "Pectus excavatum is the most common congenital chest wall abnormality occurring in 8 per 1000 live births. The defect is noticeable at birth in 86% of infants, whereas a later onset is observed in patients with Marfan syndrome. The indications for repair of pectus excavatum are essentially cosmetic."
- Reasoning: The authors provided a rationale for the review in the context of what is already known about pectus excavatum.
- Response: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
- Quote: "Our objective was to compare both the Nuss and the Ravitch procedure using systematic review and meta-analysis methodology."
- Reasoning: The authors provided an explicit statement of the research question being addressed.
- Response: [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors did not mention whether a review protocol exists or provide any registration information.
- Response: [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
- Quote: "To be selected, a study had to be designed to evaluate the Nuss vs the Ravitch procedure for the treatment of pectus excavatum and provide relevant and interpretable data."
- Reasoning: The authors specified the study characteristics used as criteria for eligibility.
- Response: [Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
- Quote: "All publications describing both surgical procedures for pectus excavatum were sought from the Cochrane Trials Register and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL) database. All studies were identified through electronic searches of MEDLINE (1966 onward), EMBASE (1980 onward), and CINAHL (1982 onward) and from hand-searching journals and conference proceedings."
- Reasoning: The authors described all information sources used in the search.
- Response: [Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
- Quote: "The terms pectus excavatum, Ravitch, and Nuss were mapped to their MeSH terms and then combined."
- Reasoning: The authors presented the search strategy used for the databases.
- Response: [Yes]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
- Quote: "Three authors (AN, AF, and PW) independently assessed all published articles identified as potentially relevant by the literature search for inclusion in the review."
- Reasoning: The authors stated the process for selecting studies.
- Response: [Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
- Quote: "Two authors (AN and PW) independently extracted data from the retrieved articles."
- Reasoning: The authors described the method of data extraction from reports.
- Response: [Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
- Quote: "The primary outcome of this analysis was complication rates. Secondary outcomes included duration of hospitalization (days), duration of surgery (minutes), time to ambulation (days), postoperative pain management, and patient satisfaction."
- Reasoning: The authors listed and defined all variables for which data were sought.
- Response: [Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
- Quote: "Quality criteria used for study inclusion included (i) appropriate selection of comparison/control group; (ii) control of factors such as selection bias, observation bias, and confounding; (iii) completeness of follow-up; and (iv) accurate outcome measurement."
- Reasoning: The authors described the methods used for assessing risk of bias in individual studies.
- Response: [Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
- Quote: "The statistical analysis was performed using RevMan 5 software. Odds ratios (OR) and weighted mean differences (WMDs) with 95% confidence intervals are presented."
- Reasoning: The authors stated the principal summary measures used in the review.
- Response: [Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.
- Quote: "We applied tests for between-study heterogeneity χ2 (Q test) and the I2 statistic to assess the appropriateness of combining studies. If the results of these tests showed heterogeneity (cutoff of 0.10 or larger for the Q test or N50% heterogeneity with the I2 statistic), a random effect model was used for meta-analysis."
- Reasoning: The authors described the methods of handling data and combining results of studies.
- Response: [Yes]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
- Quote: No relevant quote found.

- Response: [No]

- Reasoning: The authors discussed the limitations of the review.
- Response: [Yes]

18 quote(s) from publication full text (mean similarity 99.3%)


A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
- Quote: "The aim of this systematic review was to assess all available literature on neophalloplasty in infancy with an interest in technical alternatives and clinical outcome."
- Reasoning: The authors stated the research question and inclusion criteria before conducting the review.
- Answer: [Yes]

- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors did not mention the use of duplicate study selection and data extraction.
- Answer: [No]

- Reasoning: The authors mentioned the database used and the search terms, but did not mention the years of coverage or any supplementary search strategies.
- Answer: [No]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors did not mention whether they included grey literature in their search.
- Answer: [No]

- Quote: "A total of 319 articles were identified in the initial search. When limited to the pediatric population, the search was reduced to only 19 articles" [...] ""
- Reasoning: The authors mentioned the number of articles identified and included, but did not provide a list of these studies or mention any excluded studies.
- Answer: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
- Quote: "Among the different techniques presented in the 19 papers collected initially, we were able to assemble reconstructive procedures into two groups: microsurgical and non-microsurgical techniques."
- Reasoning: The authors provided some information about the included studies, but did not provide detailed characteristics of each study.
- Answer: [No]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors did not mention any assessment of the scientific quality of the included studies.
- Answer: [No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors did not mention the scientific quality of the included studies in their conclusions.
- Answer: [No]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors did not mention any methods used to combine the findings of the included studies.
- Answer: [NA]

- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors did not mention any assessment of publication bias.
- Answer: [No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
- Quote: "Conflict of interest: None. Funding: None."
- Reasoning: The authors clearly stated that there was no conflict of interest or funding.
- Answer: [Yes]


P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
- Quote: "Neophalloplasty in boys with aphallia: A systematic review"
- Reasoning: The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review.
- Answer: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- Quote: "Summary: Objective: Aphallia is a rare penile congenital abnormality. The aim of this systematic review was to assess all available literature on neophalloplasty in infancy with an interest in technical alternatives and clinical outcome. Materials and methods: We performed a Pubmed search using the terms: neophalloplasty, neophallus, and phalloplasty, and selected articles that presented technical alternatives for penile construction in cases of penile dysgenesis, especially aphallia in children and/or adolescents. Results: A total of 319 articles were identified in the initial search. Among the different techniques presented in 19 papers collected, we categorized reconstructive procedures into two groups: microsurgical and non-microsurgical techniques. Among the microsurgical techniques, procedures such as the osteocutaneous fibular flap (n Z 18), the myocutaneous latissimus dorsi flap (n Z 24), and the radial forearm free flap (n Z 293) were reported. Among the non-microsurgical techniques, we found a wider range of technical options (6 in total). Most were based on groin, abdominal, and scrotal flaps. Long-term reports on the functionability of the neophallus and psychological aspects of the patients are lacking. Conclusion: In assessing recent literature, it seems rational that neophalloplasty should be regarded as the preferred strategy for boys born with aphallia, in opposition to female gender assignment."
- Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, and conclusions.
- Answer: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- Quote: "Aphallia is a rare penile congenital abnormality found in one in every 20e30 million live male births [1,2]. The karyotype of these patients is normal (46 XY); the scrotum is well formed, and the urethra is short and opens abnormally in the rectum or anus."
- Reasoning: The authors provided a rationale for the review in the context of what is already known about aphallia.
- Answer: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
- Quote: "The aim of this systematic review was to assess all available literature of neophalloplasty in infancy with an interest in technical alternatives, advantages and disadvantages of the method, clinical outcome, complications, psychological follow-up, parental and patient penile self-perception, sexual development, and expectations of patients."
- Reasoning: The authors provided an explicit statement of the questions being addressed, including participants (infants with aphallia), interventions (neophalloplasty), and outcomes (technical alternatives, clinical outcome, complications, psychological follow-up, etc.).
- Answer: [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors did not mention a review protocol or registration.
- Answer: [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
- Quote: "We performed a Pubmed search using the terms: neophalloplasty, neophallus, and phalloplasty. We discarded articles that reported gender reassignment female to male and series of neophalloplasty exclusively in the adult population. Finally, we selected articles that presented technical alternatives for penile construction in cases of penile dysgenesis, especially aphallia in children and/or adolescents."
- Reasoning: The authors specified the study characteristics and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility.
- Answer: [Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.

- Reasoning: The authors mentioned the database used and the search terms, but did not mention the dates of coverage or the date of the last search.

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
- Quote: "Morbidity and mortality in total esophagogastric dissociation: A systematic review"
- Reasoning: The title identifies the report as a systematic review.
- Answer: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- Quote: "Abstract: Background/Purpose: Total esophagogastric dissociation has been described as both a primary and a rescue procedure for patients with severe gastroesophageal reflux. Although most commonly used in the neurologically impaired, it has also been used in those with no neurological impairment. The main objective of this study was to determine morbidity and mortality for this procedure. Methods: All published cases of esophagogastric dissociation in children were identified. Series were updated where possible by personal communication with the author. Patient characteristics, indications, morbidity, and mortality were analyzed. Results: One hundred eighty-one cases were identified. One hundred seventeen were primary operations and 64 were rescue procedures. There were 29 (16.0%) early complications and 28 (15.5%) late complications with 6 (3.3%) deaths related to the procedure of a total of 35 deaths. Twenty-one patients (11.6%) required re-operation in the study periods. Conclusions: Esophagogastric dissociation has an acceptable morbidity and mortality. It is useful as both a primary and a rescue procedure."
- Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, methods, results, and conclusions.
- Answer: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- Quote: "Total esophagogastric dissociation (TOGD) is an anti-reflux procedure originally described as a “rescue” procedure for use in children with neurological impairment (NI) by Bianchi [1] in 1997. Its use has subsequently been broadened to include neurologically normal children and adults with NI [2]. TOGD is now used as both a primary surgical procedure and as “rescue” therapy following failed fundoplication."
- Reasoning: The introduction provides the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- Answer: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
- Quote: "The aim of this study was to analyze data from all published cases of TOGD in children with particular attention to patient characteristics, indications, complications and mortality."

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
Quote: "ABSTRACT Objectives: Advances in technology and the continued evolution in the design of ureteroscopes now permit a primary endoscopic approach to the upper urinary tract of pediatric patients on a routine basis to treat a diverse group of conditions that include urolithiasis, hematuria and strictures. The purpose of this review article is to demonstrate that ureteroscopic lithotripsy is now to be considered the standard of care in the management of upper tract urolithiasis in the pediatric patient, replacing shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) as the first line of therapy. Additionally, the article will discuss the available endoscopic equipment and the lessons learned over the years to optimize the success of these procedures in children."
Reasoning: The abstract provides some information about the objectives, methods, and conclusions, but it does not provide a structured summary with all the required elements.
Response: [No]

- Reasoning: The authors provide a list of included studies but do not provide a list of excluded studies.

- Reasoning: The authors provide some characteristics of the included studies, such as the number of patients and their gender.

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
- Quote: "Systematic review and meta-analysis of enterocolitis after one-stage transanal pull-through procedure for Hirschsprung’s disease"
- Reasoning: The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
- Answer: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- Quote: "Abstract Purpose The transanal one-stage pull-through procedure (TERPT) has gained worldwide popularity over open and laparoscopic-assisted one-stage techniques in children with Hirschsprung’s disease (HD). It offers the advantages of avoiding laparotomy, laparoscopy, scars, abdominal contamination, and adhesions. However, enterocolitis associated with Hirschsprung’s disease (HAEC) still remains to be a potentially life-threatening complication after pull-through operation. The reported incidence of HAEC ranges from 4.6 to 54%. This meta-analysis was designed to evaluate postoperative incidence of HAEC following TERPT procedure."
- Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, and study appraisal and synthesis methods, but does not include study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, results, limitations, conclusions and implications of key findings, or systematic review registration number.
- Answer: [No]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- Quote: "Hirschsprung’s disease (HD) is the most common cause of intestinal obstruction in children [1]. Since the introduction of operative treatment of HD by Swenson [2], various operative procedures gradually evolved during the decades."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- Answer: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).

144. Sharp 2015: Treatment of Idiopathic Achalasia in the Pediatric Population: A Systematic Review

LLM response

30 quote(s) from publication full text (mean similarity 97.9%)


A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
- Quote: "The PRISMA format was used for the structure of this systematic review."
- Reasoning: The authors mention using the PRISMA format, but do not explicitly mention a protocol or pre-determined research objectives.
- Response: [No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
- Quote: "Independent extraction of data was performed by N.E.S using predefined data fields."
- Reasoning: The authors mention independent data extraction by one author, but do not mention a second person involved in the process.
- Response: [No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
- Quote: "Studies were identified by searching the electronic database MEDLINE (OVID), and by hand search of reference lists for further relevant articles."
- Reasoning: The authors mention using one electronic database and hand searching reference lists, which meets the criteria for a comprehensive search.
- Response: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
- Quote: "Exclusion criteria: Included abstracts, care reports, small case series (less than or equal to five cases), studies limited to treatment modalities other than PD or HM, languages other than English, studies limited exclusively to syndromic achalasia, and animal or in vitro studies."
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention searching for grey literature or unpublished studies.
- Response: [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
- Quote: "A total of seven studies were identified for inclusion in the systematic review."
- Reasoning: The authors mention the number of studies included, but do not provide a list of included and excluded studies.
- Response: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
- Quote: "All seven studies selected for the review were dedicated pediatric retrospective reviews (level III evidence) published in English between the years of 1980 and 2010."
- Reasoning: The authors provide some characteristics of the included studies, such as the type of study and the years of publication.
- Response: [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
- Quote: "Reliability of each study was determined based on the level of evidence of each study, study design, number of patients enrolled, and length of follow-up."
- Reasoning: The authors mention assessing the quality of the included studies based on several factors.
- Response: [Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
- Quote: "The optimal treatment algorithm for pediatric achalasia remains unclear as adequate comparative data between PD and HM are lacking."
- Reasoning: The authors' conclusions reflect the quality and limitations of the included studies.
- Response: [Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
- Quote: "The most significant limitation with this systematic review is attributed to the heterogeneity of the study designs and treatment methods both within and between studies."
- Reasoning: The authors acknowledge the heterogeneity of the studies and do not attempt to combine the findings inappropriately.
- Response: [NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
- Quote: Not applicable.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention assessing for publication bias.
- Response: [No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
- Quote: "Conflict of Interest: None."
- Reasoning: The authors clearly state that there are no conflicts of interest.
- Response: [Yes]


P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
- Quote: "Treatment of Idiopathic Achalasia in the Pediatric Population: A Systematic Review"
- Reasoning: The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review.
- Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- Quote: "Abstract: Background Achalasia is a rare idiopathic neuromuscular disorder of the esophagus, characterized as a syndrome of impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter and decreased peristalsis of the esophageal body. Objective The primary objective is to determine the best first-line treatment for pediatric achalasia based on the consolidation of the current literature that compares outcomes after pneumatic dilatation (PD) versus surgical myotomy (Heller esophagomyotomy [HM]). Data Sources A systematic review of English articles using OVID was performed. Study Selection OVID was used to search for articles focusing on the treatment of pediatric esophageal achalasia with PD versus HM. Data Extraction Independent extraction of data was performed by N.E.S using predefined data fields. Data Synthesis Seven articles were included in the systematic review. Techniques of HM and PD varied widely. The best first-line treatment of pediatric achalasia was determined to be HM in two articles, PD in one article, and equal efficacy in one article. Three articles concluded that appropriate initial treatment was determined by the age of the child. Conclusion Adequate comparative data are lacking to determine the ideal treatment of pediatric achalasia. Appropriately designed randomized controlled trials with long-term follow-up are needed to determine ideal treatment algorithms in pediatric achalasia."
- Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the review, including the background, objectives, data sources, study selection, data extraction, data synthesis, and conclusions.
- Response: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- Quote: "Achalasia is a rare neuromuscular disorder of the esophagus, characterized as a syndrome of impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) and decreased peristalsis of the esophageal body. Although no cure exist that can reverse the underlying neuropathology, current treatments are aimed at symptom palliation."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a rationale for the review in the context of what is already known about achalasia.
- Response: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
- Quote: "We intend to delineate the best initial treatment for achalasia and synthesize the current body of literature on outcomes from initial treatment of pediatric achalasia with pneumatic dilatation (PD) versus surgical Heller esophagomyotomy (HM)."
- Reasoning: The authors provide an explicit statement of the research question, including the participants (children with achalasia), interventions (PD and HM), comparisons (PD versus HM), and outcomes (best initial treatment).
- Response: [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
- Quote: Not applicable.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention a review protocol or registration information.
- Response: [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
- Quote: "Type of studies: Systematic reviews and retrospective reviews were included. There were no prospective randomized trials identified in the pediatric esophageal achalasia literature. Types of participants: Patients younger than 21 years. Types of intervention: PD versus HM. Types of outcomes measures: Primary outcome measure was the recommended first-line treatment of pediatric achalasia. Secondary outcome measures included type of study, level of evidence of study, length of study, diagnostic methods, number of patients, demographic information (gender and age), symptomatology, length of symptoms, procedural details, recurrence, need for further treatment, complications, and follow-up length."
- Reasoning: The authors specify the study characteristics and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility.
- Response: [Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
- Quote: "Studies were identified by searching the electronic database MEDLINE (OVID), and by hand search of reference lists for further relevant articles. The last search was run on May 4, 2014."
- Reasoning: The authors describe the information sources used in the search and the date of the last search.
- Response: [Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
- Quote: "OVID was used to search for articles focusing on the treatment of pediatric esophageal achalasia with PD versus HM."
- Reasoning: The authors mention the database used and the focus of the search, but do not provide a full search strategy.
- Response: [No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
- Quote: "Full abstracts of articles obtained by the OVID search (►Table 1) were reviewed based on inclusion and exclusion criteria clearly delineated before the start of the review process. Full articles were then reviewed and screened. Examination of references was performed and additional articles were obtained for inclusion in the discussion."
- Reasoning: The authors describe the process for selecting studies.
- Response: [Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
- Quote: "We developed data sheet (Microsoft Excel 2000 9.0.6926 SP-3, Microsoft Corporation) for our outcome measures listed earlier."
- Reasoning: The authors describe the method of data extraction.
- Response: [Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
- Quote: "Primary and secondary outcomes measures listed earlier were extracted from each study."
- Reasoning: The authors mention extracting primary and secondary outcome measures, but do not list or define all variables for which data were sought.
- Response: [No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
- Quote: "Reliability of each study was determined based on the level of evidence of each study, study design, number of patients enrolled, and length of follow-up."
- Reasoning: The authors describe the methods used for assessing the risk of bias of individual studies.
- Response: [Yes]

- Quote: Not applicable.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention any summary measures.
- Response: [No]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.
- Quote: "The most significant limitation with this systematic review is attributed to the heterogeneity of the study designs and treatment methods both within and between studies."
- Reasoning: The authors mention the heterogeneity of the studies, but do not describe any methods of combining results.
- Response: [NA]

P15. Methdos / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
- Quote: "The heterogeneity of the study designs and treatment methods results in an inherent bias resulting in the inability to perform an accurate meta-analysis."
- Reasoning: The authors mention the risk of bias across studies due to the heterogeneity of the study designs and treatment methods.
- Response: [Yes]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.
- Quote: "The search of OVID database provided 103 citations (►Fig. 1). Of the remaining articles, 81 were discarded after reviewing the abstracts as they either met exclusion criteria or failed to meet full inclusion criteria. The full texts of the remaining articles were examined. Fourteen articles were eliminated, as their focus was on PD or surgical interventions alone. A total of seven studies were identified for inclusion in the systematic review."
- Reasoning: The authors provide numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, and a flow diagram.
- Response: [Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
- Quote: "All seven studies selected for the review were dedicated pediatric retrospective reviews (level III evidence) published in English between the years of 1980 and 2010. Mean study length was 19.3  8.3 years (range, 6–30 years). Follow-up varied from 5.5 months to 22.9 years."
- Reasoning: The authors present characteristics for each study, but do not provide the citations.

- Reasoning: The authors present data on the risk of bias of each study.
- Response: [Yes]

- Quote: "The best first-line treatment of pediatric achalasia was determined to be HM in two articles, PD in one article, and equal efficacy in one article. Three articles concluded that appropriate initial treatment was determined by the age of the child."
- Reasoning: The authors present summary data for each study, but do not provide effect estimates and confidence intervals.
- Response: [No]

- Reasoning: The authors discuss limitations at the study and review level.

- Quote: "The optimal treatment algorithm for pediatric achalasia remains unclear as adequate comparative data between PD and HM are lacking. Both adult and pediatric literatures suggest that younger age may contribute to poor response to PD. Quality randomized controlled trials with long-term follow-up are needed to determine an ideal treatment algorithm."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a general interpretation of the results and implications for future research.

152. Symeonidis 2016: Laparoendoscopic single-site surgery (LESS) for major urological procedures in the pediatric population: A systematic review

LLM response

24 quote(s) from publication full text (mean similarity 98.9%)


A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
- Quote: "This systematic review was conducted in accordance to the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) guidelines [7]; a protocol was agreed beforehand by all authors."
- Reasoning: The authors mention that a protocol was agreed upon before the review was conducted.
- Answer: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
- Quote: "Two reviewers (ENS and DN) working independently extracted data from all eligible studies; any discrepancies were discussed and consensus was reached."
- Reasoning: The authors mention that two independent reviewers extracted the data and resolved any disagreements.
- Answer: [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
- Quote: "An in-depth search of the literature was performed in the databases of PubMed and Scopus, for studies investigating the technical aspects and clinical outcomes of partial nephrectomies, nephrectomies, nephroureterectomies, varicocelectomies and pyeloplasties in children."
- Reasoning: The authors describe a comprehensive search strategy using two databases.
- Answer: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention whether they included grey literature in their search.
- Answer: [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not provide a list of included and excluded studies.
- Answer: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
- Quote: "From each eligible study the following parameters were extracted when available: general study characteristics (author, date of publication), patient demographics (age and gender), procedure performed, indication, site of incision, details of surgical technique (entry device employed, access route, size of incision, laparoscopic instruments used, total operation time), intraoperative complications (including conversion to open surgery, use of additional ports and estimated blood loss (EBL)) and surgical outcome (length of hospital stay and post-operative complications)."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a detailed description of the characteristics of the included studies.
- Answer: [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
- Quote: "When applicable the methodological quality of the study was assessed using the Newcastle-Ottawa Quality Assessment Scale (NOS) of non-randomized studies."
- Reasoning: The authors mention that they assessed the quality of the included studies using a recognized tool.
- Answer: [Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
- Quote: "However given that the majority of studies included in this systematic review were either case-series or retrospective cohort studies with the risk of bias, especially publication-bias, remaining unambiguous, the results should be interpreted with caution."
- Reasoning: The authors acknowledge the limitations of the included studies and caution that their results should be interpreted accordingly.
- Answer: [Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
- Quote: "All extracted data were tabulated and the outcomes were presented cumulatively when applicable."
- Reasoning: The authors describe how they combined the findings of the included studies.
- Answer: [Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention whether they assessed the likelihood of publication bias.
- Answer: [No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
- Quote: "No conflicts of interest."
- Reasoning: The authors declare that they have no conflicts of interest.
- Answer: [Yes]


P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
- Quote: "Laparoendoscopic single-site surgery (LESS) for major urological procedures in the pediatric population: A systematic review"
- Reasoning: The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review.
- Answer: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- Quote: "Background: Improvements in laparoscopic surgery have led to the introduction of laparoendoscopic single-site surgery (LESS) as an alternative to conventional laparoscopy conferring a number of possible advantages. In this review, we aim to elucidate the aspects of LESS for major urological procedures in the pediatric population. Materials and methods: An in-depth search of the literature was performed in the databases of PubMed and Scopus, for studies investigating the technical aspects and clinical outcomes of partial nephrectomies, nephrectomies, nephroureterectomies, varicocelectomies and pyeloplasties in children. Data on parameters such as operation time, instrumentation, perioperative complications, hospital stay and follow up period were collected and further analyzed cumulatively. Results: Twenty nine studies met the inclusion criteria incorporating 386 patients who underwent 401 procedures. There were no major intraoperative complications, with only 19 patients (4.73%) facing postoperative complications. No perioperative deaths were reported. Conclusions: In the hands of experienced surgeons LESS seems a feasible, efficient and less invasive alternative to standard laparoscopy in the field of pediatric urology. There is an eminent need of well-designed randomized controlled trials comparing the two techniques."
- Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the review, including the background, objectives, methods, results, and conclusions.
- Answer: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- Quote: "Laparoscopic surgery is currently the gold standard for the surgical management of pediatric urologic pathologies [1]. Recent improvements in laparoscopic surgical techniques have led to the introduction of laparoendoscopic single-site surgery (LESS), as an alternative to conventional laparoscopy (CL) conferring a number of possible advantages: better esthetic outcome, decreased incidence of port-site complications, less postoperative pain, reduced analgesic requirements and faster recovery [2]."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a rationale for the review in the context of existing knowledge.
- Answer: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
- Quote: "The aim of this systematic review was to perform an in-depth literature search and present all the available evidence on this novel technique."
- Reasoning: The authors state the objective of the review, but do not explicitly mention the PICOS components.
- Answer: [No]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention whether a review protocol exists or provide any registration information.
- Answer: [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
- Quote: "Inclusion criteria were: 1) pediatric patient population (age <18 years) 2) single site approach initially selected by the surgeon, 3) procedure carried out completely laparoendoscopically, 4) major urological procedure performed were limited to: nephrectomy, nephrour- ureterectomy, pyeloplasty, varicocelectomy and partial nephrectomy 5) study population of more than one patient. Studies of any design, including studies comparing CL and LESS, were eligible for inclu- sion. Articles in language other than English, and studies reporting on animal models and mixed adult and pediatric population were excluded."
- Reasoning: The authors specify the eligibility criteria for the studies included in the review.
- Answer: [Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
- Quote: "A comprehensive electronic search of Medline and Scopus databases was performed with the following keywords: “Single AND (trocar OR incision OR Site) AND Surgery AND (child* OR infan* OR pediatr* OR paediatr* OR adolescen*) NOT adult”. In addition, all references were hand-searched in order to detect any potentially missed studies."
- Reasoning: The authors describe the databases used for the search and the keywords used, but do not mention the date of the last search.
- Answer: [No]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
- Quote: "A comprehensive electronic search of Medline and Scopus databases was performed with the following keywords: “Single AND (trocar OR incision OR Site) AND Surgery AND (child* OR infan* OR pediatr* OR paediatr* OR adolescen*) NOT adult”."
- Reasoning: The authors provide the search strategy used for the databases, but do not mention any limits used.
- Answer: [No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
- Quote: "Two reviewers (ENS and DN) working independently extracted data from all eligible studies; any discrepancies were discussed and consensus was reached."
- Reasoning: The authors describe the process for selecting studies.
- Answer: [Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
- Quote: "Two reviewers (ENS and DN) working independently extracted data from all eligible studies; any discrepancies were discussed and consensus was reached."
- Reasoning: The authors describe the data extraction process.
- Answer: [Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
- Quote: "From each eligible study the following parameters were extracted when available: general study characteristics (author, date of publication), patient demographics (age and gender), procedure performed, indication, site of incision, details of surgical technique (entry device employed, access route, size of incision, laparoscopic instruments used, total operation time), intraoperative complications (including conversion to open surgery, use of additional ports and estimated blood loss (EBL)) and surgical outcome (length of hospital stay and post-operative complications)."
- Reasoning: The authors list the variables for which data were sought.
- Answer: [Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
- Quote: "When applicable the methodological quality of the study was assessed using the Newcastle-Ottawa Quality Assessment Scale (NOS) of non-randomized studies."
- Reasoning: The authors describe the method used to assess the risk of bias in the included studies.
- Answer: [Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
- Quote: "All extracted data were tabulated and the outcomes were presented cumulatively when applicable."
- Reasoning: The authors mention that they presented the outcomes cumulatively, but do not specify the summary measures used.
- Answer: [No]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.
- Quote: "All extracted data were tabulated and the outcomes were presented cumulatively when applicable."
- Reasoning: The authors describe how they handled and combined the data, but this is not a meta-analysis, so measures of consistency are not applicable.
- Answer: [NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention whether they assessed the risk of bias across studies.
- Answer: [No]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention any additional analyses.
- Answer: [NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.
- Quote: "Twenty nine studies met the inclusion criteria incorporating 386 patients who underwent 401 procedures."
- Reasoning: The authors provide the number of studies included in the review, but do not provide a flow diagram or the number of studies screened and assessed for eligibility.
- Answer: [No]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
- Quote: "From each eligible study the following parameters were extracted when available: general study characteristics (author, date of publication), patient demographics (age and gender), procedure performed, indication, site of incision, details of surgical technique (entry device employed, access route, size of incision, laparoscopic instruments used, total operation time), intraoperative complications (including conversion to open surgery, use of additional ports and estimated blood loss (EBL)) and surgical outcome (length of hospital stay and post-operative complications)."
- Reasoning: The authors present the characteristics of the included studies and provide citations.
- Answer: [Yes]

- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not present data on the risk of bias within each study.
- Answer: [No]

- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not present summary data or effect estimates for each study.
- Answer: [No]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: This is not a meta-analysis, so this item is not applicable.
- Answer: [NA]

- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention any additional analyses.
- Answer: [NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
- Quote: "During the last decade the number of urological LESS procedures performed worldwide in the pediatric population has increased. Each surgeon based on his experience or preference employed different instruments and entry ports. In the hands of experienced surgeons LESS seems a feasible and attractive alternative to CL with comparable results."
- Reasoning: The authors summarize the main findings of the review and discuss their relevance.
- Answer: [Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
- Quote: "However given that the majority of studies included in this systematic review were either case-series or retrospective cohort studies with the risk of bias, especially publication-bias, remaining unambiguous, the results should be interpreted with caution."
- Reasoning: The authors discuss the limitations of the review, including the risk of bias.
- Answer: [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
- Quote: "In the hands of experienced surgeons LESS seems a feasible and attractive alternative to CL with comparable results. However, there is not enough evidence to support the superiority of LESS thus wide adoption cannot be recommended. There is an imperative need of well-designed prospective randomized trials, with large number of patients, in order to clarify the safety and long term efficacy of LESS for urological procedures in the pediatric population."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a general interpretation of the results and discuss the implications for future research.
- Answer: [Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
- Quote: "No funding received."
- Reasoning: The authors state that they did not receive any funding for the review.
- Answer: [Yes]

156. Thyoka 2013: Balloon dilatation of anastomotic strictures secondary to surgical repair of oesophageal atresia: a systematic review

LLM response

20 quote(s) from publication full text (mean similarity 99.9%)


A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
- Quote: "We decided, a priori, to limit our review to studies that reported outcomes of balloon dilatation (both endoscopically and under fluoroscopic control) of anastomotic strictures secondary to surgical repair of oesophageal atresia in children."
- Reasoning: The authors clearly state that they had a pre-determined research objective.
- Answer: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
- Quote: "Two reviewers (M.T. and A.T.) independently abstracted data from all studies onto a predefined data collection form. Any discrepancies were resolved by consensus."
- Reasoning: The authors used two independent reviewers for data extraction and had a consensus process for disagreements.
- Answer: [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
- Quote: "We searched the standard databases (January, 1960–May, 2012): MEDLINE, EMBASE and Cochrane Library Controlled Trials Register (CENTRAL) using the MeSH Terms “esophageal stricture”, “esophageal stenosis” and “balloon dilatation” to identify the studies."
- Reasoning: The authors searched multiple databases and used specific search terms.
- Answer: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention searching for grey or unpublished literature.
- Answer: [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
- Quote: "We identified 26 studies from our search that were deemed relevant and these were further scrutinised for eligibility for inclusion in this review. Only five studies met the inclusion criteria; 21 studies were excluded for reasons outlined in the selection flow chart in Fig. 1."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a list of included and excluded studies.
- Answer: [Yes]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
- Quote: "Table 1 shows the characteristics of all the studies included in this review."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a table with the characteristics of the included studies.
- Answer: [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention assessing the quality of the included studies.
- Answer: [No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention the quality of the included studies in their conclusions.
- Answer: [No]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
- Quote: "In total, 139 children (81 [58%] male) were included in this review. In total, 401 balloon dilatation sessions were performed (2.9 dilatations per child)."
- Reasoning: The authors combined the findings of the studies in a quantitative synthesis.
- Answer: [Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
- Quote: No relevant quote found.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention assessing the likelihood of publication bias.
- Answer: [No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
- Quote: "Conflict of interest None"
- Reasoning: The authors clearly state that there were no conflicts of interest.
- Answer: [Yes]

Anastomotic strictures occur in 18–30% of patients following surgery for oesophageal atresia [1]."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

- Reasoning: The authors summarize the main findings and consider their relevance to key groups.

160. Vernon-Roberts 2013: Fundoplication versus postoperative medication for gastro-oesophageal reflux in children with neurological impairment undergoing gastrostomy

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?

Reasoning: The text describes a comprehensive literature search across multiple databases.
Response: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quote: "We also performed online searches of trial registries, medical journals, conference proceedings, dissertations and theses."
Reasoning: The text indicates that grey literature was included in the search.
Response: [Yes]

Quote: Not applicable.

Reasoning: The text provides information on potential sources of support and conflicts of interest.
Response: [Yes]


P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
Quote: "Fundoplication versus postoperative medication for gastro-oesophageal reflux in children with neurological impairment undergoing gastrostomy (Review)"
Reasoning: The title identifies the report as a systematic review.
Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
Quote: "Background: Children with neurological impairments frequently experience feeding difficulties, which can lead to malnutrition and growth failure. Gastrostomy feeding is now the preferred method of providing nutritional support to children with neurological impairments who are unable to feed adequately by mouth. Complications may arise as a result of gastrostomy placement, and the development or worsening of gastro-oesophageal reflux (GOR) has been widely reported. This has led to the frequent use of surgical antireflux treatment in the form of a fundoplication, or other antireflux procedures. Fundoplication is associated with a high recurrence rate, surgical failure, and significant morbidity and mortality."
Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, conclusions and implications of key findings.
Response: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
Quote: "Children with neurological impairments frequently experience profound feeding difficulties, which can lead to malnutrition and growth failure. These are often seen as inevitable consequences of many neurological disorders due to their associated physical abnormalities, communication difficulties and motor impairments (Samson-Fang 2003)."
Reasoning: The introduction provides a rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
Response: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
Quote: "To compare the effectiveness of antireflux surgery and antireflux medications for children with neurological impairments and GOR who are undergoing placement of a gastrostomy feeding tube."
Reasoning: The introduction provides an explicit statement of the question being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design.
Response: [Yes]

Quote: Not applicable.
Reasoning: The text does not provide information on whether a review protocol exists and where it can be accessed.
Response: [No]

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quote: "The aim of the present meta-analysis study is to systematically appraise the incidence of metachronous contralateral childhood inguinal hernia following unilateral inguinal hernia repair using data from well-designed prospective studies."
Reasoning: The authors clearly state the research question and the method of using data from prospective studies.
Response: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quote: "Data from selected studies were extracted by two authors (RNV and KW)."
Reasoning: The authors mention that two authors were involved in data extraction, but it is not clear if there was a consensus procedure for disagreements.
Response: [No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quote: "The Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (The Cochrane library Issue 7 of 12, July 2014), MEDLINE (January 1966 to August 2014) and EMBASE (1947 to August 2014) were searched."
Reasoning: The authors searched multiple databases and provided the search terms used.
Response: [Yes]

Quote: Not provided.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention searching for grey literature or including unpublished studies.
Response: [No]

Quote: "Six studies met the inclusion criteria [7,28–32]. One study was restricted to male children aged 0.5 to 2 years [28]."
Reasoning: The authors mention the included studies but do not provide a list of excluded studies.
Response: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "Six studies involving 1669 children were included. Overall MCIH was 6% (95% CI from 4% to 8%)."
Reasoning: The authors provide some characteristics of the included studies, but not in a detailed or aggregated form.
Response: [No]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quote: Not provided.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention assessing the quality of the included studies.
Response: [No]

Quote: Not provided.
Reasoning: The authors do not discuss the quality of the included studies in their conclusions.
Response: [No]

Quote: "We used common descriptive and inferential meta-analysis methods to compare incidence rates and odds ratios of MCIH events across different studies and subgroups."
Reasoning: The authors describe using appropriate methods to combine the findings of the studies.
Response: [Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Quote: "Overall, a funnel plot (Appendix 4. Figure A2) did not show evidence for publication bias."
Reasoning: The authors assessed publication bias using a funnel plot.
Response: [Yes]

Quote: "Source of funding: There was no funding to the present study."
Reasoning: The authors disclose the source of funding for the review.
Response: [Yes]


P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
Quote: "Incidence of metachronous contralateral inguinal hernias in children following unilateral repair — A meta-analysis of prospective studies"
Reasoning: The title identifies the report as a meta-analysis.
Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
Quote: "Purpose: The objective of this review was to systematically evaluate the incidence of a metachronous contralateral inguinal hernia (MCIH) in children with unilateral inguinal hernia and therefore to propose or to reject routine contralateral groin exploration."
Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the review.
Response: [Yes]

Quote: "Inguinal hernia repair is one of the most commonly performed operations in pediatric surgery [1]."

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
Quote: "Inclusion criteria consisted of prospective observational studies (a), with minimal follow-up time of one year (b), assessing newborns, infants, children, adolescents and young adults, aged from 0 to 19 years (c), without contralateral groin exploration or laparoscopic closure of CPPV (d)."
Reasoning: The authors specify the eligibility criteria for the studies.

Response: [Yes]

Quote: "For MEDLINE search the following search term was used: ‘(InfantORChildORAdolescent) AND ("inguinal Hernia"OR"processus vaginalis") AND (IncidenceOR"Treatment Outcome"ORRecurrenceORLaparoscopyORcontralateralORSurgeryORExamination) AND (english[Language]ORgerman[Language])’."
Reasoning: The authors present the full electronic search strategy for the MEDLINE database.

Quote: "Data from selected studies were extracted by two authors (RNV and KW)."

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
Quote: "The primary outcome was the overall incidence of MCIH in children with unilateral inguinal hernia (i). Secondary outcomes consisted of incidence of MCIH in male versus female children (ii); in children younger than 1 year of age versus older children (iii); in children with primarily right- versus primarily left-sided inguinal hernia (iv); and in children with open versus cleft versus closed CPPV (v)."
Reasoning: The authors list and define all variables for which data were sought.
Response: [Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
Quote: Not provided.

Response: [No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
Quote: "We used common descriptive and inferential meta-analysis methods to compare incidence rates and odds ratios of MCIH events across different studies and subgroups."
Reasoning: The authors state the principal summary measures used in the review.
Response: [Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.
Quote: "We examined heterogeneity between studies with standard chi-square tests and calculated the I-square statistics, which measure the proportion of variation in treatment effect estimates due to between-study heterogeneity [14]. Depending on the result of the heterogeneity test, fixed or random effect models were used to combine the results from the different studies [15]."
Reasoning: The authors describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies.
Response: [Yes]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
Quote: "Overall, a funnel plot (Appendix 4. Figure A2) did not show evidence for publication bias."
Reasoning: The authors specify the assessment of publication bias across studies.
Response: [Yes]

Quote: Not provided.

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.
Quote: "The initial MEDLINE search yielded 2747 references. Search of CENTRAL and EMBASE database returned 304 and 3443 references respectively, none in addition to prior search. Searching the reference lists from 7 other known meta-analyses [4,6,9–12] yielded no additional studies that met inclusion criteria."
Reasoning: The authors give numbers of studies screened and included in the review, but do not provide reasons for exclusions at each stage or a flow diagram.
Response: [No]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
Quote: "Six studies involving 1669 children were included. Overall MCIH was 6% (95% CI from 4% to 8%)."
Reasoning: The authors present some characteristics of the included studies, but not in a detailed or aggregated form.
Response: [No]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).
Quote: Not provided.
Reasoning: The authors do not present data on risk of bias within each study.
Response: [No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
Quote: "A forest plot was used to summarize and visualize the results of the meta analysis (Fig. 1). Since the test for heterogeneity was significant (p-value b 0.001), results from the random effect model were used. Overall MCIH was 6%. The 95% confidence interval for the overall proportion ranged from 4% to 8%."
Reasoning: The authors present summary data and effect estimates for each study, and use a forest plot to visualize the results.
Response: [Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
Quote: "Since the test for heterogeneity was significant (p-value b 0.001), results from the random effect model were used. Overall MCIH was 6%. The 95% confidence interval for the overall proportion ranged from 4% to 8%."
Reasoning: The authors present the results of the meta-analysis, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
Response: [Yes]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15).
Quote: "Overall, a funnel plot (Appendix 4. Figure A2) did not show evidence for publication bias."
Reasoning: The authors present the results of the assessment of publication bias across studies.
Response: [Yes]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16]).
Quote: Not provided.
Reasoning: The authors do not present results of any additional analyses.
Response: [No]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
Quote: "The present meta-anlaysis shows that the overall risk of MCIH in children (aged 0–19 years) is 6%. The risk of MCIH development is significantly greater in children with initial left-sided hernia (8.5% vs. 3.3%) and in children with open CPV (13.8% vs. 3%)."
Reasoning: The authors summarize the main findings and their relevance.
Response: [Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
Quote: "Lack of uniformity in age restrictions and variation in inclusion and exclusion criteria (e.g. exclusion of patients with ascites) that were applied in different analyses may also have impacted on results."
Reasoning: The authors discuss some limitations of the review.
Response: [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
Quote: "The present meta-analysis shows, that nearly 17 (overall MCIH = 6%; 100/6 = 16.7) contralateral explorations (number needed to treat) are necessary in order to prevent one metachronous inguinal hernia."
Reasoning: The authors provide a general interpretation of the results and discuss implications for future research.
Response: [Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
Quote: "Source of funding: There was no funding to the present study."
Reasoning: The authors disclose the source of funding for the review.
Response: [Yes]

- Quote: "A systematic literature search was performed to identify articles that reported the children and infants with POI since 1990 in English-language. MEDLINE electronic database was searched in April 2013 using key words ‘‘postoperative intussusception’’. References lists of identified articles were screened for additional publications of interest."
- Reasoning: The authors describe a comprehensive literature search process, including the use of the MEDLINE database and manual search of reference lists.
- Response: [Yes]
